prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B8_CO
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This Science Goal targets: * CO(4-3) * 2x continuum

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
This Science Goal targets the CO(4-3) line. We estimate the peak flux density from Single Dish observations (beam size: 14"). The derived flux is 2000 Jy km/s. Assuming a linewidth of 200 km/s, and a filling factor of 0.1, we determine a peak flux density of 520 mJy/beam. That allows us to detect the line with a SNR of ~20 with only ~10s per pointing.
We have set up the spw, which targets the line, in FDM mode with 3840 channels (bandwidth > 1000 km/s, resolution < 1 km/s). This setup is necessary, since the emission of Cen A exhibits linewidths of a few hundred kilometers, but towards the nucleus it shows extremely narrow absorption features with FWHM < 1 km/s in all the targeted lines of this Science Goal. Since our aim is to determine the full line structure, we cannot avoid using the selected setup.
It should be noted that the nucleus exhibits a strong continuum emission of ~5 Jy. However, the high sensitivity in our spectra is only requested for regions which are offset from the nucleus, for which we expect continuum emission of the order of ~0.1 Jy.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B8_CI
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This Science Goal targets: * CI * 2x continuum

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
This Science Goal targets the line of atomic carbon CI. We estimate the peak flux density from Single Dish observations (beam size: 12"). The derived flux is 2500 Jy km/s. Assuming a linewidth of 200 km/s, and a filling factor of 0.1, we determine a peak flux density of ~850 mJy in a 1" beam. That allows us to detect the line with a SNR of ~20 with only 10 s per pointing.
We have set up the spw, which targets the line, in FDM mode with 3840 channels (bandwidth > 1000 km/s, resolution < 1 km/s). This setup is necessary, since the emission of Cen A exhibits linewidths of a few hundred kilometers, but towards the nucleus it shows extremely narrow absorption features with FWHM < 1 km/s in all the targeted lines of this Science Goal. Since our aim is to determine the full line structure, we cannot avoid using the selected setup.
It should be noted that the nuclues exhibits a strong continuum emission of ~5 Jy. However, the high sensitivity in our spectra is only requested for regions which are offset from the nucleus, for which we expect continuum emission of the order of ~0.1 Jy.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B7_CO
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This Science Goal targets: * CO(3-2) * HCO+(4-3) * 2x continuum

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
This Science Goal targets the CO(3-2) line. We estimate the peak flux density from Single Dish observations (beam size: 14"). The derived flux is 680 Jy km/s. Assuming a linewidth of 200 km/s, and a filling factor of 0.1, we determine a peak flux density of ~180 mJy in a 1" beam. That allows us to detect the line with a SNR of ~25.
We have set up the spw, which targets the line, in FDM mode with 3840 channels (bandwidth > 1000 km/s, resolution < 1 km/s). This setup is necessary, since the emission of Cen A exhibits linewidths of a few hundred kilometers, but towards the nucleus it shows extremely narrow absorption features with FWHM < 1 km/s in all the targeted lines of this Science Goal. Since our aim is to determine the full line structure, we cannot avoid using the selected setup.
It should be noted that the nucleus exhibits a strong continuum emission of ~5 Jy. However, the high sensitivity in our spectra is only requested for regions which are offset from the nucleus, for which we expect continuum emission of the order of ~0.1 Jy.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B7_13CO
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This Science Goal targets: * 13CO(3-2) * C18O(3-2) * 2x continuum

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
This Science Goal targets the 13CO(3-2) line. We estimate the peak flux density from Single Dish observations (beam size: 14"). The measured flux is 80 Jy km/s. Assuming a linewidth of 200 km/s, and a filling factor of 0.1, we determine a peak flux density of ~20 mJy in a 1" beam. That allows us to detect the line with a SNR of ~8.
The largest angular scale of the 13CO emission is expected to be of the same order as the 12CO, but we restrict ourselves to scales < 7 arcsec. The main goal of the 13CO observations is to determine the position-dependent line ratio of 13CO/12CO. In order to reliably determine it, we will restrict the 12CO data to the same uv-ranges as for the 13CO observations, which allows us to effectively determine the line ratio on scales < 7 arcsec (130 pc).
We have set up the spw, which targets the line, in FDM mode with 3840 channels (bandwidth > 1000 km/s, resolution < 1 km/s). This setup is necessary, since the emission of Cen A exhibits linewidths of a few hundred kilometers, but towards the nucleus it shows extremely narrow absorption features with FWHM < 1 km/s in all the targeted lines of this Science Goal. Since our aim is to determine the full line structure, we cannot avoid using the selected setup.
It should be noted that the nucleus exhibits a strong continuum emission of ~5 Jy. However, the high sensitivity in our spectra is only requested for regions which are offset from the nucleus, for which we expect continuum emission of the order of ~0.1 Jy.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B7_HCN
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This Science Goal targets: * HCN(4-3) * HCO+(4-3) * 2x continuum

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
This Science Goal targets the HCN(4-3) line. We estimate the peak flux density from Single Dish observations (beam size: 14"). The derived flux is 62 Jy km/s. Assuming a linewidth of 200 km/s, and a filling factor of 0.1, we determine a peak flux density of ~16 mJy in a 1" beam. That allows us to detect the line with a SNR of ~8.
We have set up the spw, which targets the line, in FDM mode with 3840 channels (bandwidth > 1000 km/s, resolution < 1 km/s). This setup is necessary, since the emission of Cen A exhibits linewidths of a few hundred kilometers, but towards the nucleus it shows extremely narrow absorption features with FWHM < 1 km/s in all the targeted lines of this Science Goal. Since our aim is to determine the full line structure, we cannot avoid using the selected setup.
It should be noted that the nucleus exhibits a strong continuum emission of ~5 Jy. However, the high sensitivity in our spectra is only requested for regions which are offset from the nucleus, for which we expect continuum emission of the order of ~0.1 Jy.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B6_HCN
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This Science Goal targets: * HCN(3-2) * HCO+(3-2) * 2x continuum

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
This Science Goal targets the HCN(3-2) line. We estimate the peak flux density from Single Dish observations (beam size: 12"). The derived flux is 56 Jy km/s. Assuming a linewidth of 200 km/s, and a filling factor of 0.1, we determine a peak flux density of ~19 mJy in a 1" beam. That allows us to detect the line with a SNR of ~8.
We have set up the spw, which targets the line, in FDM mode with 3840 channels (bandwidth > 1000 km/s, resolution < 1 km/s). This setup is necessary, since the emission of Cen A exhibits linewidths of a few hundred kilometers, but towards the nucleus it shows extremely narrow absorption features with FWHM < 1 km/s in all the targeted lines of this Science Goal. Since our aim is to determine the full line structure, we cannot avoid using the selected setup.
It should be noted that the nucleus exhibits a strong continuum emission of ~5 Jy. However, the high sensitivity in our spectra is only requested for regions which are offset from the nucleus, for which we expect continuum emission of the order of ~0.1 Jy.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B6_HNC
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This Science Goal targets: * HNC(3-2) * 3x continuum

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
This Science Goal targets the HNC(3-2) line. We estimate the peak flux density from Single Dish observations (beam size: 12"). The derived flux is 34 Jy km/s. Assuming a linewidth of 200 km/s, and a filling factor of 0.1, we determine a peak flux density of ~12 mJy in a 1" beam. That allows us to detect the line with a SNR of ~8.
We have set up the spw, which targets the line, in FDM mode with 3840 channels (bandwidth > 1000 km/s, resolution < 1 km/s). This setup is necessary, since the emission of Cen A exhibits linewidths of a few hundred kilometers, but towards the nucleus it shows extremely narrow absorption features with FWHM < 1 km/s in all the targeted lines of this Science Goal. Since our aim is to determine the full line structure, we cannot avoid using the selected setup.
It should be noted that the nucleus exhibits a strong continuum emission of ~5 Jy. However, the high sensitivity in our spectra is only requested for regions which are offset from the nucleus, for which we expect continuum emission of the order of ~0.1 Jy.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B3_CO
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This Science Goal targets: * CO(1-0) * 3x continuum

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
This Science Goal targets the CO(1-0) line. We estimate the peak flux density from Single Dish observations (beam size: 22"). The derived flux is 600 Jy km/s. Assuming a linewidth of 200 km/s, and a filling factor of 0.05, we determine a peak flux density of ~120 mJy in a 1" beam. That allows us to detect the line with a SNR of ~30 in only 8 minutes on source.
We have set up the spw, which targets the line, in FDM mode with 3840 channels (bandwidth > 1000 km/s, resolution < 1 km/s). This setup is necessary, since the emission of Cen A exhibits linewidths of a few hundred kilometers, but towards the nucleus it shows extremely narrow absorption features with FWHM < 1 km/s in all the targeted lines of this Science Goal. Since our aim is to determine the full line structure, we cannot avoid using the selected setup.
It should be noted that the nucleus exhibits a strong continuum emission of ~5 Jy. However, the high sensitivity in our spectra is only requested for regions which are offset from the nucleus, for which we expect continuum emission of the order of ~0.1 Jy.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B3_13CO
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This Science Goal targets: * 13CO(1-0) * C18O(1-0) * CS(2-1) * 1x continuum

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
This Science Goal targets the 13CO(1-0) line. We estimate the peak flux density from Single Dish observations (beam size: 22"). The derived flux is 60 Jy km/s. Assuming a linewidth of 200 km/s, and a filling factor of 0.05, we determine a peak flux density of ~12 mJy in a 1" beam. That allows us to detect the line with a SNR of ~8.
The datarate exceeds the policy value of 12 MB/s, because we have 3 spws set up in FDM mode, using 3840 channels each (bandwidth > 1000 km/s, resolution < 1 km/s). This setup is necessary, since the emission of Cen A exhibits linewidths of a few hundred kilometers, but towards the nucleus it shows extremely narrow absorption features with FWHM < 1 km/s in all the targeted lines of this Science Goal. Since our aim is to determine the full line structure, we cannot avoid using the selected setup.
It should be noted that the nucleus exhibits a strong continuum emission of ~5 Jy. However, the high sensitivity in our spectra is only requested for regions which are offset from the nucleus, for which we expect continuum emission of the order of ~0.1 Jy.
The largest angular scale of the 13CO emission is expected to be of the same order as the 12CO, but we restrict ourselves to scales < 7 arcsec. The main goal of the 13CO observations is to determine the position-dependent line ratio of 13CO/12CO. In order to reliably determine it, we will restrict the 12CO data to the same uv-ranges as for the 13CO observations, which allows us to effectively determine the line ratio on scales < 7 arcsec (130 pc).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B3_HNC_HCN
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This Science Goal targets: * HNC(1-0) * HCN(1-0) * HCO+(1-0) * 1x continuum

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
This Science Goal targets the HNC(1-0) and HCN(1-0) lines. We estimate the peak flux densities from Single Dish observations (beam size: 57"). The derived fluxes are 130 and 250 Jy km/s. Assuming a linewidth of 200 km/s, and a filling factor of 0.01 (due to the large beam size), we determine a peak flux density of ~20 and ~38 mJy/beam, which allows us to detect the line with a SNR > 8.
The datarate exceeds the policy value of 12 MB/s, because we have 3 spws set up in FDM mode, using 3840 channels each. This setup is necessary, since the emission of Cen A exhibits linewidths of a few hundred kilometers, but superposed on that are extremely narrow absorption features with FWHM < 1 km/s in all the targeted lines of this Science Goal. Since our aim is to determine the full line structure, we cannot avoid using the selected setup.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
The core of the radio galaxy Centaurus A is (i) a supermassive black hole (SMBH) surrounded by (ii) a circumnuclear disk (CND) from which matter falls in towards (iii) a central hot inner zone where much of the infalling material is deflected into (iv) an outflow of gas at modest speeds along the much faster particle jet emanating from the SMBH. We will use ALMA to image and fully resolve disk, central hot zone, and outflow at a resolution of 20 pc (1") in order to determine the physical and dynamical structure, excitation mechanism and interaction of the core components using the models developed by us and others specifically for such a purpose. The ALMA observations will for the first time reveal the detailed spatial distribution of gas motion, density, temperature, mass, and heating agent in the vicinity of an accreting nuclear black hole.
The CND, the gas reservoir fuelling both the SMBH and the outflow, is the key to understanding the evolution of the radio galaxy and its active nucleus. The nearness of Centaurus A combined with ALMA resolution and sensitivity makes it the best possible target for such a study.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2012.1.00019.S Probing the merger remnant disk in the giant elliptical galaxy NGC5128 F.P. Israel

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: ALMA Project Office, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
